meanings.definition: To kill by squeezing the throat or neck
meanings.sent1: The villain tried to strangle the hero with a rope.
meanings.sent2: The python can strangle its prey with its powerful coils.
meanings.sent3: I joked that the tangled headphones seemed to strangle each other.
meanings.sent4: The vines seemed to strangle the life out of the old tree.
meanings.sent5: The boa constrictor's ability to strangle its victims is both fascinating and terrifying.

meanings.sent1: Fear can sometimes strangle our ability to speak up.
meanings.sent2: The tight collar seemed to strangle his neck.
meanings.sent3: The traffic jam seemed to strangle the flow of cars.
meanings.sent4: The economic crisis threatened to strangle small businesses.
meanings.sent5: The thick fog seemed to strangle the city, hiding everything in its grasp.

meanings.sent1: She had to strangle her laughter during the serious meeting.
meanings.sent2: The authoritarian regime tried to strangle any form of dissent.
meanings.sent3: The overprotective parent seemed to strangle their child's independence.
meanings.sent4: The heavy workload seemed to strangle her creativity.
meanings.sent5: The silence in the room seemed to strangle any chance of conversation.
